Crazy dataset you encounter infrequently—from Bank of England's "millenium of macroeconomic data." @kjhealy calls it, "Escaping the Malthusian trap"—animation of England's compared w/ estimates of GDP per capita; runs from 1270 to current times (2016). Caveats notwithstanding (where to begin?😂 ), shows largely positive impacts of technology, advances in societal/economic organization (incl. capitalism) & plague's adverse impact. https://kieranhealy.org/blog/archives/2023/01/08/escaping-the-malthusian-trap/
#dataviz #economics#development #progress

Pass it on! NBER innovation bootcamp is happening again this year, organized by Kevin Bryan, Ina Ganguli, Ben Jones, and Kyle Myers. It’s a one-week deal (inclusive of NBER SI innovation sessions), with travel and accommodation costs covered. Open to ~25 students who have finished 2 yrs of Econ PhD coursework or recent PhDs in research positions. See https://www.nber.org/nber-innovation-research-boot-camp-2023 for more. @innovation

title: Furby 1998 source code : David Hampton, Wayne Schulz : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
The Furby source code is public and heavily commented. For example, it turns the microphone off when the motors are running.

Furby was the 1998 version of ChatGPT and tons of people thought it actually slowly learned English words. The NSA was alarmed. However it turned out the "learning" process was just on a timer and the "microphone" only triggers on loud sounds.
https://archive.org/details/furby-source

City officials have found around a dozen of the antennas and no one is sure what they're for. One of the finest pleasures in life is to discover a complete series of novels as an adult, to devour them through to the end, and to arrive at that end to discover that, while you'd have happily inhabited the author's world for many more volumes, you are *eminently* satisfied with the series' conclusion.

If you'd like an essay-formatted version of this thread to read or share here's a link to it on pluralistic.net, my surveillance-free, ad-free, tracker-free blog:

So check this out: this would be pretty simple to do with a bot and I have one as a WIP.

https://neuromatch.social/@jonny/109552710007394939

Detect mentions of papers, create root post for that paper, link back all times it is mentioned. Mentioning the paper gets you a link back to the root post.

So: Underneath that root post you can have "canonical" discussion. but all other times paper is mentioned are also indexed from the root post, so you can also talk about it anywhere and have it archived back.

lmk if ya wanna work on this together, have talked about it a bit in the discord (see the announcement top of your home feed) :)

title: Papers with Code - Attributed Question Answering: Evaluation and Modeling for Attributed Large Language Models

last_post.content: There's a whole cottage industry right now looking at the limits of #ChatGPT (e.g. it can't double-check claims or do external attribution) and turning those limits into sentences that begin "Language models can only ever ..." I get why this is a reassuring, widely circulated message, but I wish a few people circulating it would mention that there is already active research that seeks to address those limits. https://paperswithcode.com/paper/attributed-question-answering-evaluation-and

I do think there are opportunities to use tech to reduce the procedural work of connecting with others, while keeping the effort high.

We had some promising results with experiments on “digital handcrafting” last year.

If you're into retrocomputing stop what you're doing and check out Medley Interlisp, a restoration of the software environment of Xerox Lisp Machines rehosted on modern systems.

It's the most fascinating and advanced software development environment I've ever seen. I posted about my first impressions, why I love Medley Interlisp, and how I plan to use it:

https://journal.paoloamoroso.com/my-encounter-with-medley-interlisp

#interlisp #LispMachines #lisp #retrocomputing

last_post.content:
I work on an app called Actions for Obsidian. It's the missing link between #macOS and #Obsidian: it adds 30+ actions to Apple Shortcuts for a deeper Obs integration into macOS (and later, iOS).

I think you'll like it.

A few spots on the current beta just opened up: https://testflight.apple.com/join/CPFTNadV It's not feature complete yet but I'm happy enough with my progress to have more people give it a go.

The Chronocyclegraph was developed by Frank Gilbreth and his wife, Lillian in the early 20th century. The couple employed small lamps on worker's hands and time-lapse photography to reduce a work cycle to the most efficient sequence. Gilbreth was the first to propose that a nurse could assist the surgeon, by handing them surgical instruments. He also devised the techniques used to teach how to rapidly disassemble and reassemble weapons.

https://we-make-money-not-art.com/the_chronocyclegraph/

title: GitHub - rougier/book-mode: A clean interface for org files (Emacs)

last_post.content: #emacs Book mode is an attempt at offering an interface for reading org-mode files with a clean layout. It is based on the use of large margins, headline and mode-line, with leading stars and bullets in the left margin using right alignment and different symbols. All decorations are part of the header-line (including upper left colored part and right upper glyph) and messages are displayed in the mode-line. Code at https://github.com/rougier/book-mode

title: China, a Pioneer in Regulating Algorithms, Turns Its Focus to Deepfakes

last_post.content:
China is pushing ahead in regulating deepfakes and generative AI.

New rules on Tuesday will ban the use of AI-generated content for spreading "fake news”—and require providers of “deep synthesis” technologies to visibly label content that looks real.

While the former bucks international norms, the latter follows them.

title: An Open Letter to the C++ Community | Alice (pseudonym)

last_post.content:

The journal Meta-Psychology envisions a radically open way to publish.

It is free to publish in, open access, open peer review. Data and materials are required to be made publicly available. All statistical analyses are reproduced by their team to ensure reproducibility. They allow "evolving papers" where updates, replications, commentaries are added as links in the original paper webpage.

https://open.lnu.se/index.php/metapsychology/index
#OpenScience #Science @academicchatter #AcademicChatter #AcademicPublishing

title: View of How social media could teach us to be better citizens

last_post.content: What if building better social media platforms wasn't just good for escaping narcissistic billionaires? What if it could help us become better and more effective citizens? That's my argument in this paper: http://www.je-lks.org/ojs/index.php/Je-LKS_EN/article/view/1135818/1333

My latest in Puck on #TikTok & a possible ban:

"It’s risky to build on someone else’s property. Ownership of our data, social graph, and financial relationships has great value. How many times do we have to lose our followers on a social network to realize they were never ours? Unless we have a way to reach them outside the walled garden, such as an email address, mobile number, or credit card number, then they belong to the garden, not to us. We’re just sharecroppers."

https://puck.news/tiktok-on-the-clock/

title: Nature announces support for authors from over 70 countries to publish open access | Corporate Affairs Homepage | Springer Nature

last_post.content:
From today, research papers accepted-in-principle (the step before formal accept) in Nature or one of the Nature research journals (e.g., Nature Chemistry) from corresponding authors based in countries classified by the World Bank as low-income (LIC) or lower-middle-income economies (LMICs) can be published gold open access at no cost.

#OpenAccess #OpenScience

https://group.springernature.com/gp/group/media/press-releases/nature-announces-support-for-authors-to-publish-open-access/23894926

It’s January 9, and I just read the best article I will read all month.

“Social Quitting” by @pluralistic

“Once a platform has its users and business customers locked in, it can enshittify its service to the point of near uselessness without losing either, allocating all the useful surplus in the business to its shareholders.”

“The important thing about the Fediverse isn’t that it’s noncommercial or decentralized—it’s that its design impedes surplus harvesting.”

https://doctorow.medium.com/social-quitting-f049b33ad3f6
